A simple USB power distribution block. Hook it up to a 5v power supply (like ATX) and plug in as many devices as you need for your project. I use mine to power a raspberry pi, a teensy and a ethernet/wifi bridge.

Get straight USB connectors made for circuit boards. The STL has room for three, but the scad file is parametric, so if you want to have 47 of them, go ahead.  Insert the USB connectors into the holder, bend the side tab on each one out to keep it in place. Also make sure to squish the inside springs a little as inserting usb cables will be very tight otherwise.  Solder the data pins (the middle ones) together on each usb connector, then connect pin 1 and pin 4 to the power as shown. (Make sure you get + and - right, I'll let you figure out which is which so you can't blame me if you get it wrong.) Once everything is hooked up, simply press the holder into the back part. It should be a snug fit which will not require any glue.  Use double-stick tape or velcro to attach it wherever you need it.

comments.author: tbillion

comments.text: I like your implementation better than what I had.  I got a box of the USB sockets and made a 7-port charger by soldering them vertically to a protoboard and wiring that to plug into a HDD power plug on an old desktop power supply.  Plenty of amps at 5VDC there.  And no, don't plug your laptop into this, there's no reason to.  Plus, anything you're typically charging from USB would be a single-cell lithium battery, with a max. voltage around 4V, so there will be electronics between the USB power and your battery; you aren't going to discharge-charge anything unless one of your devices is very badly designed.

title: Elektriktrick STL, DXF, and GCode QuickLook for Apple OS X (including Mavericks)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Current Version is 1.1.0. QuickLook is a wonderful thing on Mac: just hit the space bar with any file selected, and a big preview of that file will be shown instantly. Unfortunately this will not work for STL files. Older QuickLook implementations will no longer work for Mavericks as OpenGL rendering is no longer possible due to sandboxing.
.
Elektriktrick STL QL uses standard graphics to get around that limitation, It works for QuickLook previews as well as for Icon previews.
.
Version 1.1.0 adds an application that previews files, just as QuickLook does. It also fixes some minor issues with the QL plugin that is now part of the app. Please remove previous installs of the QL plugin.
.
Download the zip file and uncompress it by double-clicking it. Then open the extracted disk image and move the Elektriktrick app into your Applications folder. Launch Elektriktrick from within the Applications folder once to make the contained QuickLook plugin known to macOS.
.
Older versions:
.
  • Version 1.0.1 changes the camera position to a more common location
  • Version 1.0.2 adds GCode rendering for files anding in .gcode and .bfb
  • Version 1.0.3 fixes issues with Mavericks and makes installing easier by providing a simple app that is dragged into the /Applications folder
    • elektriktrick.com

[DEBUG] Previewing file:///Users/who/Downloads/web/cornercube.stl. Content type UTI: com.pleasantsoftware.uti.stl. Generator used: None

comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: HA! If you can't beat 'em, join 'em. Adding com.pleasantsoftware.uti.stl to the LSItemContentTypes array in the quicklook plugin's info.plist made it work!
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text:
To clarify for anyone trying to reproduce this, I did Show Package Contents on the quicklook bundle, opened info.plist in a text editor, then changed this:
<key>LSItemContentTypes</key>
<array>
<string>com.elektriktrick.stl</string>
</array>
to this:
<key>LSItemContentTypes</key>
<array>
<string>com.elektriktrick.stl</string>
<string>com.pleasantsoftware.uti.stl</string>
</array>
There's probably another identifier that Autodesk 360 is using that can be added to the list to make it work without removing that. The output from the qlmanage -d... terminal command below should tell you what this identifier is.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

The MDF bed provided with the Ormerod is too floppy and is better replaced with an aluminium one. The problem is the complex cut-outs required (usually laser cut) to fit this on the bed support means that normal people cannot cut this. Therefore I have produced a one-piece bed support with a flat top enabling you to use any bed you wish with only simple drilling which can be more easily done at home. You can even use this support with the original MDF bed if you like by drilling 3 mount holes as shown in the photos and it does support the floppy MDF better. I have done this as I found my aluminium bed too heavy so I am drilling chunks out of it to reduce weight.
By making a the bed a single piece I have reduced manufacture time, increased rigidity, eliminated beam/back alignment problems and eliminated connecting screws.

Simply print the component; it has been through 4 iterations to ensure a perfect fit. The bearing mount is tight; this is intentional to ensure it does not slip off. It also covers more than 180 degrees of the bearing so it cannot slip around vertically and change the bed level during a print like the original plywood part does. The holes in the rear plate are elongated to allow perfect bed support alignment relative to the Z post. To attach the belt, simply overlap, tension and slide/press into the groove as you do with the original part. This should be sufficient but if you do get slippage problems, there are two holes under the belt position which you can tap using an M3 screw and use a pair of nylon M3 screws to secure the belt. To secure your bed to the support, drill 3 x 4mm holes to line up with the 3 holes in the support.
If using a bed of the original dimensions (215 x 215) then the third hole should be located 27.5mm from the centre of the front edge of the bed. This is a guide only, please confirm the before you drill. Countersink your holes.
The holes in the support will need to be tapped using an M3 screw. The original countersunk M3 screws then work to attach the bed.

title: Vertical X-Carriage for PBC Linear Slide

description.text:
I have since moved on to a different design, while this mount worked well for me for almost a year, it limits access for necessary maintenance. I will keep it up here, but recommend exploring other options. Here is what I am currently using on the same slide:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:291980

This is for anyone that converts to the PBC linear slide but wants to keep using the popular Jonas Kuehling's Greg's Wade extruder. Works only with the J-Head Mrk IV-B or another equally tall hot-end. For shorter hot-ends the shelf on the mounting plate needs to be moved lower and the cold end made taller for the motor to clear the carriage. I have uploaded the SolidWorks file for easy modification. There are too many hot ends out there to make a one size fits all solution since the shorter the hot-end the taller the extruder body has to be for the motor to clear the carriage. This is more of a personal solution for my specific set of hardware as a stop-gap until I move to a micro extruder. For a fan mount to go with this carriage see:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38893

You will have to print a modified extruder body, I attached one sliced for .25 mm but you can render your own from the attached OpenSCAD file.  I only changed two major things: set elevation = 13 from the default 2, and set motor_mount_rotation = 0.  You only need to print a new extruder body; idler, gears, and hardware are all the same.

description.text: This bottle clip helps me carry my requisite 20oz bottle of Diet Mountain Dew.  It also works on the Deer Park water bottles that my wife likes.  If you carry one of those bottles between your fingers it can hurt on a long hike.  This solution is a little more fun and a lot more comfortable on the fingers.

Print the two parts and use a piece of filament for the hinge.  I used the hot nozzle on my makerbot with the Z-axis raised up as a welding tool to stake the hinge to the clip. I was able to melt, squash, and smooth the ends of the filament hinge pin in a sort of welding/staking operation.

comments.text: I just printed it and the design is amazing! I still have some questions/remarks:
comments.author: murx

comments.text: so this has nothing to do with upgrade or making print size bigger? its just replacement. then why not make same as printrbot shape like original part because it looks easier and uses less filament?
comments.author: norbu1987

comments.text: I built it.  As long as you have big enough rods and long enough GT2 belts, you can extend your X axis as much as you want.  I had some problems with by belts slipping so I had to add a guide post, but with $10 in materials, I have a 150mm x axis, which could easily be longer if I bought a bigger aluminum print bed.
comments.author: norbu1987

comments.text: I can't figure out how to install the tension block securely. Does anyone have pictures of how they did it?
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: I just folded the GT2 belt over and pinched it off with a nylon zip tie.  BTW, in order to get this to work with even the stock bed, you will need longer rods and GT2 belts
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: Does this fit on stock GT2 belt?
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: Belt may need to be longer, but the belt type is the same.
comments.author: quillford

comments.text: So, I'm running into an issue after installing the re-mixed version of this upgrade. I've used the new ends to attach the Printrbot simple build volume upgrade's print bed to my simple. However, when the x axis travels this much distance, the GT2 belt slowly slips off of one of the bearings until it comes off completely.
comments.author: thecrazytaco

comments.text: You could try adding oversize washers to act as flanges on the bearings. I have incorporated these into my bearing caps on recent designs.
comments.author: thecrazytaco

comments.text: Thanks for the reply! Can I find these bearing caps in the thing files of one of your designs? They sound like they would be really useful. If not, any recommendations on washers? I dropped by my local home depot, but the only oversize washers I could find were 1" ones that were hilariously large for the simple's bearings.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: You will find some for 608 bearings, but I believe the stock 1405 uses 624 which are smaller and less common.
comments.author: thecrazytaco

comments.text: I wouldn't mind swapping in 608 bearings, provided that they fit. Not sure of the size difference between the bearings, but if they don't fit the stock simple, I'll just wait until I can print your X axis overhaul. Right now I can print 150mm on the x axis without the bearing slip getting bad, which I think is juuuuust barely big enough to print the parts for your overhaul.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: Can you print this on a standard printrbot?
comments.author: CodeRedCardinal

comments.text: I have uploaded an "Oriented" version where it will fit on an 100 x 100 build area.  Had to trim a little, but it will make it.

comments.text: It seems that on my 1405 Printrbot simple that my build area is more like x: 97mm, y:100mm, Z:100mm, and so I can't print this part. Does anyone else with the stock 1405 have this problem, or are you getting the full 100mm x-axis area as advertised?
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: Mine did the same thing. I found that it wasn't calibrated correctly. More info here: https://printrbot.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/202227454-Default-Steps-Per-Millimeter

It is not compatible with the 2014. The rods are spaced differently.
I thought I had a version for the stock 2014 setup (without double precision), but I cannot seem to find it. If I have time I may go back and adjust the 2014 upgrade.

comments.text: many thanks Jon
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: Will you eventually modify this design to be double precision?
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text:
This specific one, no. It uses the 624 bearings which are not globally available. I prefer to use the 608 bearings which can be found anywhere.
I have another thing in the works which can be single or double precision along with better performance.

title: Elliptical Gear Set with connecting links.

description.text: Elliptical gears and some connector links to play around with.  I got the idea for these when i was thinking about an old steam locomotive.  I have been playing with them for a couple weeks and wanted to upload something.  I may design some more connecting links and different shaped gears that go with this in the future.  I will upload them if i do.

Printing without raft works best for me...   with ABS set your HBP to 120c, extruder to 230c and let her rip.... i have printed dozens with no failures.   Don't be too forceful when you snap these together.  Sometimes one of the 3 prongs will break off on a connecting link.  i started out with 4 and had too beef them up and knock it down to 3 to get them to stop breaking.  
Please post pics of what you assemble from these... i would love to see them..  
ENJOY.

title: Low-Poly Pikachu
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I would love to keep sharing my projects with all of you. If you enjoy with my designs, I invite you to become a patron, you will get early access to my designs and exclusive content! Also, you can help with a small donation. Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

NOTE: You can check my newest designs in my YouMagine profile! More Low-Poly and other simple designs! https://www.youmagine.com/users/flowalistik Designing a low-poly Pokemon is the best way I found to represent the poor graphic quality the first Pokemon games had. So, here I present you the low-poly Pikachu, which is part of the Low-Poly project I'm developing. 3D printers allow to make real the idea of catching all Pokemon, and I'm currently working to make all the Pokemon I can. You can check the collection in the following page: http://www.thingiverse.com/FLOWALISTIK/collections/low-poly-pokemon This model is 5cm tall approximately. The model from the picture was printed with a Prusa i3, 0.2mm layer height, 0.5mm nozzle, 45mm/s speed and a cooling fan (I really recommend this!). The material is 3mm high quality PLA. It was designed so it doesn't need support material, although each printer is different and it may be more difficult to print it depending on the settings. // This design is based on Pokemon

comments.text: you should check the minimum time between layer box value to maker sure enough time is spent between layers to cool down. This either slows the head down or causes a pause before advancing. Additionally enabling the move printer head away from object feature will ensure excess heat is not transferred from the hot end to the print. It is very useful when doing the ears as the warping is from the hot end smearing the plastic around
comments.author: bkjpl

comments.text: Thanks for the advice but Makerbots don't have "minimum time between layer" or "move printer head away from object" capabilities.
comments.author: Nedrathul

comments.text: that is a good alternative solution if no software solution can be found having an additional small fan directly attached to the print head will help with preventing warping. I have used large fans to cool the entire object build space with better results but this can easily effect your hot end temperature. The last option is to have multiple objects printing at the same time. Having the print head move between two of the same objects ramps up the print time but can give the cooling time needed in between printing the ears.
comments.author: bkjpl

comments.text: If you see the Pikachu models that have already been printed, at least half of them have problems with the ears. I print using PLA, a cooling fan (so the plastic solidifies as soon as it's extruded) and a slow speed. I would suggest you to print slower and with a lower temperature, but these are pretty general tips as every 3d printer is different!

comments.text: same with dan. I've printed many things very cleanly, but between the ears and tale, its all stringy and not a nice finish. I've noticed this before when the temp is a bit high or the speed might be a touch fast and its draging some unmelted PLA over.

comments.text: I print exclusively with PLA, and this problem you're talking about is really common if the extruding temperature is higher than required. Also, not using a cooling fan for PLA lowers the print quality.The problem about sharing a 3d model is that the result depends more on the printer than on the model, the only thing I can recommend is: print slower, extrude with a lower temperature and use a cooling fan.

title: Embossed Snowflake Gift Tag - Monogram
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
It's Christmas! Time to decorate the tree with some custom decor. Hang this on the tree as a cusom initialed ornament, or use as a gift tag!
My inspiration for this came after I spent well over $10 on "artsy" gift-tags of various designs. They look GREAT on the gifts, but I honestly hate throwing them away. It seems like another huge waste that isn't necessary this time of year. So here you have my customized monogram gift tag. I wanted to make something small, beautiful, that was as memorable as something you'd find in the store but that I could print at home. I have put this design through a few changes, but really just to accomodate multiple symbols.
As per suggested, I am entering this in protoparadigm's December Design Contest! I'm so honored that this tag has been used and can spread the joy of the holidays and love of 3D printing at the same time. I hope that you find this gift-tag as fun to print and tie on a gift as I did. Happy Holidays!

100% Infill
Bed Temp: 117 C
Layer Height: .28
Material: ABS (White)
No Support required as long as the letter and snowflake extrusions face upwards! :)
EDIT
Added Letters A-Z
No idea how to make this one file if there is a way.

description.text: A tiny turret that doesn't shoot anything yet, just aims a little plastic stick around. I may glue a super-bright LED to the end of it.

This is three parts, and it requires two super-cheap servos from HobbyKing http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__7476__Turnigy_1370A_Servo_3_7g_0_4kg_10sec.html The base is tricky; mine didn't print very well but I fixed the baked-in support structure so that hopefully yours prints better. 1) attach the 'gun' to the (large single-sided) upper horn, but leave the horn off of the servo
2) slide the upper servo into the turret and anchor it with a little piece of wire through the wire anchor hole
3) slide the servo-horn/'gun' assembly through the assembly notch and attach it to the upper servo by sticking a screwdriver through the screwdriver hole
4) screw the lower servo horn (large double-sided) onto the bottom of the turret, making sure it's exactly lined up in the center. the horn should be perpendicular to the long axis of the turret.
5) slide the lower servo into the slot in the base, running the servo wires through their respective holes and out the bottom

description.text:
We were making a gift for a friend's retirement. We already had several homemade cleaning products in jars and my wife wanted to include hand soap but didn't want to break the trend of it being in glass jars. I made this to fit a typical store bought foaming hand soap pump. I may make another version with taller threads to fit another type that we have around the house.   
Edit: I made and uploaded the version with taller threads but I haven't printed and tested it yet. Let me know if you get to it before I do!

Because of the nature of the print I did have to print it with the pump threads up, which means the canning jar part is upside down compared to a normal print. I did use support to print and then had a lot to clean out under the canning lid. However, it did turn out great and functional!

description.text: Decorative bowl with honeycomb pattern. Scale the axes to get different shapes.

Made in Google Sketchup by intersecting a hexagonal pattern with two half spheres. I uploaded that sketchup file in addition to the STL. This item is probably a great candidate to scale the axes independently to get different shaped bowls, repetier for example lets you do this. It has a flat spot on the bottom so will not need a raft, but it will need support for the first half of the layers to print properly. The only overhangs are on the outside though, so the support can be easily removed. Skeinforge seemed to generate much more useful support structures than slic3r. The default STL is about 14.5cm in diameter and 5cm high, and was run through netfabb once and should be fairly error free. The attached photos were printed on a solidoodle 2 at 80% scale and sliced with skeinforge at .2 mm layers.

Hi there,
This is a pen test of my new built Rostock 3D printer.
I used pronterface to draw 10 mm squares on the paper but as you
can see the result is horrible!
I built my Rostock based on the original design and used Marlin firmware and double checked everything including mechanic and electronic parts,but it seems that the problem persists.
Any suggestion would be appreciated.
Thanks in advance

comments.text:
I'm feeling rather self concious being the only one to have posted here for a while, and having posted so much! I have an update though - you inspired me to try the same tests on my printer, and I now think I know what's going on with yours. The only way you could possibly have boxes whose corners don't line up like that is if you have backlash issues, or as ModernGnome suggested, your pen is loose (giving a similar effect to backlash). Even if all your delta arms were different lengths, that's the only way you can have corners that don't line up.
I see the same issue on my printer because I haven't set up any sort of bed levelling yet and I was using a biro rigidly bolted to the effector. As the pen pushes harder on the paper, the backlash becomes visible due to flex in the pen and effector. I also had wavy lines, but that's due to having twice as many square root operations - the processor can't keep up!
As to fixing it, you'll have to work out where the wobble is coming from. It could be anything from the pen holder through the joints all the way to the belts driving the carriages. Home the system then move it down in Z in pronterface. Keep the motors on (but stopped) and try wobbling the pen with your fingers. If there's movement, try and figure out what it is that's allowing the movement to occur - that will be what you need to find a way of making more rigid.
comments.author: PolyVinalDistillate

comments.text:
The more I look at your output pattern, the more I think it could be an arm length mismatch... Have you tried just doing straight lines of arbitrary length? Then you can check how straight they are after with the ruler. Since I have discovered Y in pronterface is aligned to a tower-centre axis, I think you should find that drawing a straight line from 0,0 to + or - Y should give you a straight line. Drawing from 0 to + or - X probably won't. Once you move to a nonzero X coordinate, arm length mismatch would stop you getting straight lines in any direction (X or Y) I think.
If Y motion at X=0 doesn't give you straight lines, then that suggests that the effector is moving in Z too and putting extra pressure on your pen, causing it to push the effector off the intended path. This would hint at rod length mismatch of one sort or another too.
Now, assuming that you get straight lines when moving from 0,0 along Y, I would then start swapping the motor connections (so, by my convention, towers alpha, beta and gamma become beta, gamma and alpha respectively, then gamma, alpha, beta), and check the same patterns again. If one of the rods is too short or too long, it should show up as the pen pressing harder or lifting off the paper as it moves along Y.
Note - I define 0,0 as being the centre of the build plate, and when I say along Y, I'm assuming that is the axis you get straight lines because tower alpha moves up while beta and gamma both move down by the same amount as one another (or vice versa).
comments.author: PolyVinalDistillate

comments.text:
I've been building my own variation of the rostock from scratch with only very minimal reference to pictures of delta printers. I realised (after I painstakingly designed the parts) that the hinges have to be coaxial or you have to use ball joints if you want to use the marlin firmware as it stands. The model you have posted rather reminds me of my hinge design, although without seeing what it connects onto I can't be sure. Anyway, the upshot is that if you designed your own joints and the up/down rotation isn't coaxial with the side/side rotation, you need an extra square root per delta tower in the the firmware inverse kinematics! If this is the case, I can furnish you with the equations I worked out for my design, although the extra square roots may eat up too much CPU time (I've not got as far as the pen test yet).
On another note - is there an option to draw 10 mm boxes built into pronterface? I've not found it yet...
comments.author: PolyVinalDistillate

Looks like it's lined up to Y and not X (which is odd, because I'm almost certain I derived my IK equations lined up to X and not Y).
comments.author: Pirouzan

comments.text:
Ooops - I clicked on the 'vote down' instead of 'reply'! So I clicked on 'vote up' afterwards to make up for it! If you're using the standard joints then you shouldn't have the problem I encountered. That leaves backlash in the joints (which should have been solved by the elastic bands), uneven lengths of delta arms, or wrong lengths of delta arms I think.
I see how you've drawn the pattern - I was going to look into writing G-Code to draw test patterns when I get back onto the project. Your approach seems more sensible for an initial test! Although I'm not entirely sure about the pronterface X,Y movement control... to my mind, either X or Y should be on the same axis as one of the tower-to-centre lines, but my initial observations suggested that neither X or Y are setup to coincide with a tower-to-centre. To explain a different way, if the towers are alpha, beta and gamma coords, then I would expect X increments to move alpha down while beta and gamma both move up by an equal amount. Either that or I would expect the same when I moved in Y. This didn't appear to be the case... Perhaps you should look into typing in G codes to do the movement instead?
Anyway, as I have pointed out before, I am also new to this conundrum and my have got the wrong end of the stick! Perhaps someone with more experience of pronterface can reassure us both that we can rely on the manual x, y movement in pronterface.
comments.author: Pirouzan

comments.text: This is, of course, assuming that the problem is not with whatever is holding that red pen in place. :-)
comments.author: ModernGnome

comments.text: Give that the lines vary so much near the corners (for example, the rightmost line on the top right square, and the one below it), I'd say that this indicates "slop" caused by loose joints between the carriage/diagonal rods/effector assembly. Some folks attach a rubber band on two clips between each of the two parallel rods just above the effector to minimize the sloppiness. But you may also need to add washers to get things more precise at the effector ends. I hope this helps.
comments.author: ModernGnome

Not the most efficient use of a 5-pack of walker mechanisms, but somewhat more amusing.
Now with video!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LompQ0sTG28

Print the head with support.
Catbodyf is the "regular cat" configuration, with all four legs moving forward.
Catbodyproto allows you to install either walker mechanism forward or backwards. I thought running them in opposite directions would result in enhanced bobblehead action at the expense of forward motion, but this was not the case in real-world testing. Removing the mechanisms to switch directions is also much more difficult with the tolerances of my latest Replicator-printed body. I used the 35mm spring pin for the neck and the 75mm snake pin for the tail. I did not alter the parts, they are interchangeable with the other parts at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17725 so if you'd rather make a giraffe cat, you can.

description.text:
These are based off of the popular KÃ¼hling's X ends (18384) but have been modified to work with RichRap's quick-fit x carriage (19590) as well as mine (37675).  These should fit any x carriage, if not let me know what needs to be corrected and I will fix it.
The only issue I had with KÃ¼hling's X Ends was that I would not be able to use them for my X Carriage due to the belt clamps being 7.2mm further off of the axis.  Instead of shifting the weight of the stepper motor 7.2mm further off to the side, I decided to place it behind the Z Rod to help center it's weight.

author: DrMark

description.text: Made on Tinkercad, Fake Diamond ring unless created with a diamond substance along with gold

The Cam-Locks on the Manfrotto tripod model 728B are prone to cracking due to a thin wall thickness.  The body of the cam-lock sees a tremendous amount of stress which over time leads to a catastrophic failure (hopefully not when you have a $2000 DSLR mounted on it).  In my opinion, a high-end tripod shouldn't have a $0.25 molded part that is prone to cracking and costs $15ea to replace.
The model I generated has a wall thickness of almost 4mm at its thinnest compared to the factory's 2mm.  I haven't put it through temperature cycling and aging, but I am confident it will hold up better than the original.

• Start from the smallest tube and replace one section at a time.
  • Remove the rubber foot.
  • Remove the old Cam-Locks by pushing out the brass pins with a hammer and drift (any punch or small screwdriver smaller than the pin diameter will work). Save the pins, the cam levers and the rectangular pressure block that falls out.
  • Pull off the old Cam Lock body.
  • Slip on the newly printed body. A rubber mallet helps, but it shouldn't be necessary. There is a rectangular hole in the tube....The opening in the cam-lock body should line up with the hole.
  • Drop in the pressure block into the hole of the cam-lock body. The pressure block is slightly curved on one face....This should face the cam lever.
  • Position the cam lever in the body with the lever in the open position. Press in the brass pin with a rubber mallet.
  • Repeat for the remaining sections.

description.text: Lost your base plate? This one fits a variety of smaller fluid heads and is surprisingly strong.
I made this on Tinkercad.
A motorized version of the Big Love Heart Gears.

If you already have made the Big Love Heart Gears then simply remove Gear 8 (the bottom gear) and the pin from the center block.
Print the modified Gear 8 (in the same color as the rest of the Big Love Heart Gears), the motor drive shaft and then the stand (in the desired color, I think black looks good here but I painted mine with metallic gold paint due to a shift in the Y-axis on my print, using PLA this is a lot of work).
You will need an AC power cord, synchronous AC motor, AC cord connector, lighted AC power switch (DPST), a 4 connecter terminal block, several 3mm screws and some glue.
There are two versions of the motor drive shaft. Version 1 is designed to be glued into the normal Heart Center piece and Version 2 is designed to be connected to the RHM Heart Center w/o any glue. The advantage is if somehow it gets broken it is much, much easier to replace but requires that you print out the Heart Center with the modified bottom hole to accept the Version 2 of the motor drive shaft.
In the motor base there are only the matching holes for the modified Gear8 but none for your AC motor. This is because there are so many different designs I thought it was easier to simply mark the holes and drill them in the old fashioned way.
I soldered wires to the AC connector and AC switch. The base was screwed into the modified Gear8 using three 3mm screws (because the 4th will be covered by my AC motor). The AC motor was then positioned to the center of the hole and the various holes in the motor were marked on the bottom of the base and drilled with a 2mm cordless drill. The motor was then fastened using four 3mm screws. A 4 conductor terminal block was glued to the bottom of the AC motor and used to connect the wires up properly. The AC connector was connected to the 0 (off) side of the AC switch and the 1 (on) side of the AC switch was connected to the AC motor. This way the light only lights when the motor is running. If wired the other way around then the light would always be lit as long as the AC connector is receiving power. The terminals were protected to prevent electrical shock from probing fingers.
Plug it in, turn it ON and enjoy!
You can view a video of the motorized Big Hear Gears in action on YouTube (below).
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=09_gzU3U-9U
At the request of AndreV added another HeartCenter with an even bigger hole to hold the V2 connector. This has been printed and approved by AndreV.

description.text:
Print a tag to match the gift box with receivers initials. Happy Holidays! This is a negative space variant of the original snowflake gift tag.
My inspiration for this came after I spent well over $10 on "artsy" gift-tags of various designs. They look GREAT on the gifts, but I honestly hate throwing them away. It seems like another huge waste that isn't necessary this time of year. So here you have my customized monogram gift tag. I wanted to make something small, beautiful, that was as memorable as something you'd find in the store but that I could print at home. I have put this design through a few changes, but really just to accomodate multiple symbols.
As per suggested, I am entering this in protoparadigm's December Design Contest! I'm so honored that this tag has been used and can spread the joy of the holidays and love of 3D printing at the same time. I hope that you find this gift-tag as fun to print and tie on a gift as I did. Happy Holidays!

100% Infill
Bed Temp: 117 C
Layer Height: .28
Material: ABS (White)
No Support required!
I'd love to hear from you! Please post your pic of the design in its' new home.

description.text:
Diese Version des MK8 Extruders kontrolliert den Anpressdruck mit einfachen Gummibänder. Damit kannst Du ganz einfach den gewünschten Anpressdruck einstellen. Die Teile werden einfach gegen das weiße Kunststoffstück ausgetauscht.
Als mechanischen Umfang brauchst Du:
  • Kugellager DIN 625 -> AD16 / ID5 / D5 (-> das die gleichen wie beim Makerslideprofil / Hadron / OrdBot benutzt wird.)
  • Scheibe M4 DIN 125
  • beliebige Gummibänder
    Bei läuft die Version seit 2 Wochen problemlos. Ich hab da noch ein kleinen Putzi eingebaut. Damit verstopft die Düse weniger.

    (Googletranslate)
    This version of the MK8 extruder controls the pressure with simple rubber bands. To be able to adjust easily to the desired pressure.
    The parts are simply replaced with the white plastic piece.
    As hardware will need:

  • Bearings (DIN 625) AD16 / ID5 / D5 (-> the same as the Maker Slide Profile / Hadron / OrdBot is used.)
  • Washer M4 DIN 125
  • Any rubber bands
    In the version runs fine for 2 weeks. I got there a little Putzi installed. Thus, the nozzle clogged less.

description.text:
I have a bunch of USB cables on my desk at work for various projects that plug into a 7-port USB hub. I'm in a cubicle and run the extra lengths of cable behind the desk and back up to the devices. I find is difficult to identify which cable is plugged in where at the hub, so to solve this I made an oscilloscope probe style identifier. These are designed for 4mm cables as is, but can be customized to fit any cable. I have not tried this out yet, so the dimensions may need some tweaking.
Just customize and print two of the same color at 100% fill. Probably best to use ABS, but I'm sure PLA would work just fine as well. Snap these on a cable just behind the strain relief of each connector. Print pairs in different colors to allow for easy identification.

title: ABS Sun Gears for Emmetts Automatic Tranmission Model

description.text:
I had very bad curling problems while trying to print the sun gears in ABS... the overhanging cone in the center kept curling up and then the extruder would hit it.  I realized it only curled away from the brake tab, because the brake tab was holding it from curling.  So as a solution, I added 2 more brake tabs, I also widened the small part of the cone just a little bit to reduce the overhang distance.   I also had problems with the gear teeth curling up from the platform, so I printed them with a brim in slic3r and that solved the problem, trimming the brim off was not too hard, as I made it wide enough (6mm) so I could just grab it and pull it away from the gear.   This is posted as a work in progress because I am still printing the rest of the parts to assemble this and I'm not completely sure there will be clearance for 3 brake tabs, although it appears to be fine in openscad.
Update:  I have my transmission model finished and assembled and these gears are working great with it!
Print these Sun Gears with 3 Tabs when using ABS.   These were printed with a single extruder head pausing and changing colors after layer 5.

A pop screen/spit guard for a microphone.
Simple design. Quick to print.
You supply the screening fabric.
spit-catch.stl is both halves, Part1 and Part2 are the two parts split because they didn't both fit on my printer's bed. It's not perfect, but it works and it took me longer to write this post than the .scad file, and that's one of the things 3d printing is all about, isn't it?

Firstly, I designed this for what I had on hand. Obviously I still need to run to the store and get hardware to finish this. It is a two piece print with registration divots to hold the fabric between and bolt holes to hold the pieces together.
I didn't actually design with a bolt size in mind, so find something that will fit at your hardware store.
Currently, I'm using binder clips to hold it together, a piece of scrap MDF to hold it to my mic stand, and a piece of facial tissue as fabric. It works well, actually.
For the fabric, you will want something thin, but probably more substantial than tulle. At least, I did. Specifically, I was looking to block my exhalations of breath from sounding on the mic. But you don't want to go too thick either, because then you're muffling the sound.

description.text:
In the spirit of Rahsaan Roland Kirk, we designed a mouthpiece for the Anarchestra that was supposed to play 2 instruments at the same time. Then we printed a prototype on a 3D printer in ABS plastic, and attached it to 2 homemade musical instruments. However, the experiment did not work. We could only get sound from one, but not both, of the instruments (from the pipe with the hole closest to the mouthpiece). Perhaps we could get the mouthpiece to work by tweaking the design. Specifically, we might add a separator in the middle -- between the arc and the reed holder -- in the throat of the dual mouthpiece. That separator might be as thin as a razor blade, and would be added lengthwise (parallel with the blowing air, in order to avoid creating additional turbulence). Perhaps the 2 resulting new chambers in the throat cylinder would also have to be enlarged, for acoustical reasons. (If one could print the dual mouthpiece in glass (or maybe see-thru plastic), he might blow smoke through the transparent dual mouthpiece to see the turbulence, and then redefine the design to get rid of that turbulence) There are other flaws in the design:

  • The slope of the reed holder needs to be adjusted so that the reed fits snugly on the dual mouthpiece, without leaving a gap.

  • The housing of the reed holder section needs a slight bulge around its circumference, so that the metal reed holders can slip over the mouthpiece housing, and securely hold the reed to the mouthpiece.

  • Also the tip of the mouthpiece needs to be rounded slightly, whereas in our design the tip is straight.
    • Anyone is welcome to download the file and improve the design. Rahsaan Roland Kirk: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aVU34lV3fVc#t=00m22s Anarchestra: http://www.anarchestra.net/index2.php More creations on my Posterous blog: http://krrrl.posterous.com/

Why not switch to inline reed styles (i.e. bassoon, oboe, bagpipe chanter or drone) instead of the mouthpiece style you currently have pictured and have one reed in each channel after they have split from each other. I would think you would need a rather soft grade of reed though to be able to activate both reeds using only your breath.

description.text:
Convert new or broken Monster Acrylic tubes into Dice Holders and/or Dice Tower; We have several of these tubes from Monster - used to hold playmats; a few seem to chip or crack on the closed ends after being dropped or shoved precariously into a bookbag... instead of throwing them out, we converted a few to hold dice and use them as dice tubes/towers using these inserts. Depending on wear/tear you will need to saw off the closed end or use a hole saw drill bit to cut out a feeder hole to drop your dice in; or fall out depending on your preference. I'll probably rework this for standard circular acrylic tubes (2" diameter) note: I've had to modify the percentage scale a little depending on whether I printed them using an Afinia or a Rep2x; ymmv I printed the two (alternating) single units at 0.30mm height taking about ~90 minutes to print... no support needed; printed 6 and slid them gently into the tube; no glue needed, friction held. I have not printed the alternating units with the mana symbols within them yet; that's lined up for this weekend. The tube rings are used to slide over the acrylic tube as 'grips'; careful not to snap them when sliding over the outside. Fee free to tinker here:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eyfz5slycTL-monster-acrylic-playmat-tube-dice-tower-single https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ercbcvyK9xF-monster-acrylic-playmat-tube-dice-tower

This is a base and disc for making a helmet mounted cyclist rearview mirror.
Added a generic mirror mount, more common mirror disc mount for one inch 25.4mm mirror discs, and a stencil for DIY cutting mirror discs.

1-Print these two parts at 10% size
2-Insert a mirror into/on the disc holder of your choice, secure with glue or double side tape
3-Attach base to helmet with double sided tape
4-Insert wire or an unforlded paperclip into the base
5-Bend other end of the wire 90 degrees down
6-Insert bent end of wire into the mirror disc carrier
7-Once you have the distance right and can see behind you mark the wire
8-Secure the wire in the base and mirror disc with glue, I use hot glue
9-If(when) you ruin the wire or loose the mirror print another and reattach It is also possible to heat the wire and insert it hot to secure it to the base and disc. OpenSCAD files are included to edit if you need a different base or mirror carrier disc. edits:
-I have added a 25.4mm(one inch) stencil so you can easily cut out a disk from a cheap hand mirror or broken mirror piece with a carbide glass scribe.
-I increased the size of the disc to accomidate the imperial size mirror discs, a 25mm disc will also fit so deleted the first posted holder.
-I also added a generic mirror mount that will accept any mirror you like using double sticky tape, just be sure to bevel sharp edges.

I noticed one of those children's toys with an animal where you push the base and the animal collapses. As usual I immediately said "i can print that!" :)
This should be possible to print without support on most printers.
Additional requirements:
=
Wool of your choice.
Big spring that fits inside the base.
Nylon or thin string that is fairly strong.
Instructions:
=
Print the build plate. Take thin (but strong) thread through from the base to the head (Inner base->Outer base->Big flat 1/2 bead->Leg bead->Leg bead->Body->Neck bead->Head). tie around wool and thread back down in reverse (leaving through the other hole).
Ditto for the hind quarters.
I tensioned it by putting the big spring inside, then pushing the inner base up while pulling the strings until the body stood by itself and the inner base was slightly recessed into the outer base. I pulled each string over the bottom lip, then using a rubber band I strapped the strings to the outside of the outer base and used superglue on each of the strings where they leave the holes on the inner base. Wait until dry, then trim the strings down to size. The poor horse should collapse if you push the inner base, then recover when you release. It should also stand on it's own without the strings at the bottom interfering. Fluff the wool hair to give the look you want.
Give it a whirl and let me know what you think?
Also suggestions for other projects!
TODO:
=
Find out why some slicers causes glitches around the eyes.
Adjust hole sizes for thinner string.
It would be awesome if I could print the spring - seems a bit of a challenge to make decent printable springs though.

title: Swivveling Sprite-bottle holder for RAM look-a-like mounting

description.text:
My son is a "Sprite" fan ánd he drives a motorcycle.
So the demand was for a cub holder for his bottles :-)

  • This should be mounted to my thing:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:375381
    Warning: use only soft drinks when controlling your motorcycle!

  • Please 'LIKE' before collecting!
    Thomas
    www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

As all my RAM look-a-like material,
I slice on 0.25mm layers with 40% infill and solid infill every 15th layer Don't print the 'mockup' file, it is there for illustration only!
The idea is to put small bolts through the swivel and the cup holder, with a washer in between.
Also bolt one knob to the middle hole, knob facing outward, make sure not to tight strong (use self locking nuts) so everything can swivel.
Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

this is something i threw together real quick. 2 candle holders. these were printed with madesolid pet+ then airbrushed and faux finished to give a semi rusted old metal appearance. the rope is 3/8" natural sisal available right at home depot. the ends of the rope are glued in place with a little epoxy to keep it from unwinding. once the rope is on burn the hairs off with a small torch or lighter so its not so fuzzy and to give the rope a slight aged look. submerse the candle holder and rope in water for about an hour then take it out and let it dry. the rope will shrink up a little and get even tighter around the holder. there is a cap file. this piece goes under the candle. you can fill the inside with sand or something heavy if you want then put the cap on and glue in place or even leave it empty then you can use it for a secret hiding place.

title: Prusa P3Steel Y smooth rod block

description.text:
I made this little piece to block Y smooth rod of prusa P3Steel (Leonardo type by Irobri) because rods are cutted at 340 millimiters and they will end at the edge of frame without any possibilities to block them. Using this piece, you can secure rods to frame without any other modification to them such as threated hole on each side to use washer and screw or making longer rods and block them using Sieger ring, or any other things.
It is also possibile to fix this block to the frame using n°2 screws but in my case (using P3Steel frame painted) it is not necessary because they will stay very tight!
Enjoy ^_^
Slide it from top over Y rod's guides, that's it.

description.text: My wife wanted a case for Christmas.  At $0.50 of plastic, I figured, why not?

This requires the use of dualstrusion.   Under RepG, choose Merge STL for Dualstrusion (Ctrl-D shortcut) and specify the two files.  Output to a separately named .gcode file.
The .tcw file is the TurboCAD file that I used to manipulate the original iphone5case6 designed by Helmi74 to create the knocked-out case and the part (tree) that goes into it.
The "corner pins" are there to help center the pieces.  Unfortunately, TC exports STL with the origin set to the minimum coordinates of the object -- which makes it nearly impossible to align the offsets of nested objects without some guide piece.  The pins are located at opposite corners of the overall design, so you can just "center on platform" and it'll work.
Enjoy!

author: toybuilder

description.text: Our SteadiCam operator is always trying to find ways to reduce weight. I printed an adapter to use the standard Sony Viewfinder mount instead of an arm to mount the camera's teleprompter. The prompter moves less and the rig is almost a pound lighter.

At first I was going to try and mount an "adapter" directly to the Teleprompter monitor, but decided to add a standoff to move the monitor further forward.  
I used acetone to bond the adapter and standoff, but added holes for an M3 flathead screw to add strength.  
The other end of the offset has a hole where you can thread a standard 1/4"-20 screw (I cut the head off and threaded it into the standoff).

I'm not sure where this puzzle originated; it's old. Arguably, it is not even a puzzle in the sense that it consists of only a single piece, but it's a great way to annoy your normally-good-at-math friends. The goal is to determine the area of the ring formed by the difference between two concentric circles given only the length of a chord which is tangent to the inner circle. In this case, the chord is, as clearly marked, 10cm long.

This is a trivially easy print in one color. The raised text is then highlighted using paint or, as shown here, permanent marker.
What is the area of the ring?

STOP READING HERE IF YOU WANT TO FIGURE IT OUT YOURSELF. You could solve this puzzle by doing a bit of trig, but using a little idea from calculus is much easier. The key is the realization that the length of the chord is the only thing that matters. If that was not true, the problem would be unsolvable without additional information. Thus, we can freely change the radii of the circles -- and when the inner radius approaches zero, the trig gets very easy. If the inner circle radius is zero, so is the area of the smaller circle that we need to subtract from the area of the larger circle. Even better, the chord becomes the diameter of the outer circle. Thus, we can use the good old Pi(rr) formula. Here, r=10/2 cm, so the area must be 25Pi cm2. Incidentally, if you want to make people think this problem is even harder, be sure to call the circular ring the annulus. That ought to get them thinking that they need to remember even more trig. ;-)

comments.text:
SPOILER
Don`t read this, if you want to solve the problem yourself.
Here is another way to solve this:
Think
of a square of width a=10cm. Inscribe a circle that touches the inside
of the square and "out-scribe" a circle that touches all corners. The
answer will be the same as in the instruction.

We all know the the story of Cory Doctorow...   Decked out in red cape and goggles, he watches over us from his balloon fortress somewhere in the blogosphere, just above the tag clouds.
What many of you may not know is exactly what he protects us from.  You see, Cory Doctorow has an evil twin from the Mirror Universe, the evil DR.ow EVIL, commander of MAFIAA army...  a ruthless terrorist organization determined to suppress all innovation.  Behind every DMCA takedown, lurking in the space between SOPA revisions, whispering into the ears of every corrupt politician... DR.ow EVIL is there.

This is the latest v12.12.12 update to Cory's scanned head, meshed into a printable action figure head.  Yeah, it's just a replacement head you can put on the Cyberman body, but it was a quick and easy mashup.  An XKCD Hero version Cory is coming...  but capes are difficult to model so I don't know when.  
Some assembly required.  Some parts not for use with some sets.  Collect them all.
